abstract.text: The physics simulation attributes attached to a scene graph node.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: When SceneKit prepares to render a new frame, it performs physics calculations on physics bodies attached to nodes in the scene. These calculations include gravity, friction, and collisions with other bodies. You can also apply your own forces and impulses to a body. After SceneKit completes these calculations, it updates the positions and orientations of the node objects before rendering the frame.
To add physics to a node, create and configure an
object and then assign it to the
property of the
object. A physics body must be associated with a node object before you apply forces or impulses to it.
The
class defines the physical characteristics for the body when it is simulated by the scene. Three properties are most important for physics simulation:
The
property, which determines how the body interacts with forces and other bodies in the simulation.
Static
bodies are unaffected by forces and collisions and cannot move.
Dynamic
bodies are affected by forces and collisions with other body types.
Kinematic
bodies are not affected by forces or collisions, but by moving them directly you can cause collisions that affect dynamic bodies.
The

property, which defines the three-dimensional form of the body for collision detection purposes. Physics simulations run faster when using simple shapes instead of the fine detail of a node’s visible geometry. Typically, you set a body’s physics shape to a bounding box, sphere, or primitive shape that roughly matches its node’s visible content. For details on creating physics shapes, see
The
property. Applying a force or torque to a dynamic body results in an acceleration (or angular acceleration) proportional to its mass.

All values in SceneKit’s physics simulation use the International System of Units (SI): The unit of mass is the kilogram; the units of force, impulse, and torque are the newton, newton-second, and newton-meter; and the unit of distance for node positions and sizes is the meter. Note that you need not attempt to provide realistic values for physical quantities—use whatever values produce the behavior or gameplay you’re looking for.
For a dynamic body, you can control how the body is affected by forces or collisions. See Defining How Forces Affect a Physics Body.

content.text: Defining a Body’s Category and Collisions

inlineContent.text: When you design a game that uses physics, you define the different categories of physics objects that appear in the scene. You define different categories of physics bodies for the behaviors your want for your app. A body can be assigned to as many of these categories as you want. In addition to declaring its own categories, a physics body also declares which categories of bodies it interacts with.
Use the
and
properties to define an object’s collision behavior. The constants listed in
provide default values for these properties. In addition, with the
property you can define interactions where a pair of bodies generates contact messages (see the
protocol) without the bodies being affected by the collision.
Physics fields create forces that affect all bodies in an area, such as vortices and gravitational attraction. For details and a list of available field types, see
You can add higher-level behaviors that control interactions between multiple bodies, such as joints and wheeled vehicles. For details and a list of available behaviors, see
A scene’s
property holds an
object that manages physics characteristics that affect the entire scene.
SceneKit evaluates its physics simulation as part of the rendering loop described in

. On each pass through this loop, SceneKit determines the state of all nodes with attached physics bodies, and simulates the effects of physics on those bodies for one time step—for example, by updating the position or rotation of a body based on its velocity and angular velocity. After simulating physics, SceneKit applies the results of the physics simulation to the scene for display.

Because you can animate SceneKit content not only through physics, but also through actions and implicitly and explicitly defined animations, SceneKit applies the results of physics simulation not to the
objects in your scene, but to each node’s
object that represents its currently displayed state. As such, changing properties of a node that are affected by physics  requires special consideration.
If you change the
value—or any of the other properties that are components of the transform, such as
and

—of a node affected by physics, SceneKit resets the physics simulation for that node. If you want to change only one component of the transform, while leaving the others at their physics-simulated values, copy the presentation node’s transform before making changes, as shown below:

code: // Copy the presentation node's transform to the model node.
// Change one component of the new transform
// Copy the presentation node's transform to the model node.
// Change one component of the new transform

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
A structural element of a scene graph, representing a position and transform in a 3D coordinate space, to which you can attach geometry, lights, cameras, or other displayable content.
The physics body associated with the node.
The translation applied to the node. Animatable.
A node object representing the state of the node as it currently appears onscreen.
The node’s orientation, expressed as a rotation angle about an axis. Animatable.
The transform applied to the node relative to its parent. Animatable.
The abstract superclass for joints, vehicle simulations, and other high-level behaviors that incorporate multiple physics bodies.
The physics simulation attributes attached to a scene graph node.
A Boolean value that specifies whether SceneKit can automatically mark the physics body at rest.
A factor that reduces the body’s angular velocity.
A vector describing both the current rotation axis and rotational speed (in radians per second) of the physics body.
A multiplier affecting how SceneKit applies rotations computed by the physics simulation to the node containing the physics body.
Applies a force or impulse to the body at its center of mass.
Applies a force or impulse to the body at a specific point.
Applies a net torque or a change in angular momentum to the body.
A mask that defines which categories this physics body belongs to.
The position of the body’s center of mass relative to its local coordinate origin.
The electric charge of the body, in coulombs.
Cancels all continuous forces and torques acting on the physics body during the current simulation step.
A mask that defines which categories of physics bodies can collide with this physics body.
A mask that defines which categories of bodies cause intersection notifications with this physics body.
The minimum distance the body must travel for SceneKit to apply a more precise (but more costly) algorithm to detect contacts with other bodies.
A factor that reduces the body’s linear velocity.
Creates a physics body that can be affected by forces and collisions.
The body’s resistance to sliding motion.
Creates a physics body with the specified type and shape.
A Boolean value that determines whether the constant gravity of a scene accelerates the body.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the physics body is at rest.
Creates a physics body that is unaffected by forces or collisions but that can cause collisions affecting other bodies when moved.
The mass of the body, in kilograms.
The body’s moment of inertia, expressed in the local coordinate system of the node that contains the body.
An object that defines the solid volume of the physics body for use in collision detection.
Updates the position and orientation of a body in the physics simulation to match that of the node to which the body is attached.
A factor that determines how much kinetic energy the body loses or gains in collisions.
The body’s resistance to rolling motion.
Tells SceneKit whether to treat the body as currently being in motion.
Creates a physics body that is unaffected by forces or collisions and that cannot move.
A constant that determines how the physics body responds to forces and collisions.
A Boolean value that determines whether SceneKit automatically calculates the body’s moment of inertia or allows setting a custom value.
A vector describing both the current speed (in meters per second) and direction of motion of the physics body.
A multiplier affecting how SceneKit applies translations computed by the physics simulation to the node containing the physics body.
Constants that determine how a physics body interacts with forces and other bodies, used by the
property and when creating a physics body.
Default values for a physics body’s
and
properties.
Methods you can implement to respond when a contact or collision occurs between two physics bodies in a scene.
An object that applies forces, such as gravitation, electromagnetism, and turbulence, to physics bodies within a certain area of effect.
An abstraction of a physics body’s solid volume for tuning collision detection.
The global simulation of collisions, gravity, joints, and other physics effects in a scene.
The physics simulation associated with the scene.
Methods your app can implement to participate in SceneKit’s animation loop or perform additional rendering.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
